hints.content: Start by understanding what a palindromic string is. A palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 'racecar' is a palindrome.
Since the input string is guaranteed to be palindromic, you can leverage this property. Think about how characters are arranged in a palindrome: they mirror around the center.
To generate the smallest lexicographic palindrome, consider how the characters can be rearranged. Count the frequency of each character in the string.
Remember that in a palindrome, characters must appear in pairs, except for potentially one character that can sit in the middle if the length of the string is odd.
As you count the characters, think about how to construct half of the palindrome. The first half will determine the second half due to the mirroring property.
Sort the characters by their lexicographic order. This will help you ensure that the first half of the palindrome is the smallest possible arrangement.
Once you have the sorted characters, build the first half of the palindrome. If there is a character that appears an odd number of times, it will be placed in the middle.
After constructing the first half, remember to append the reverse of this half to complete the palindrome.
Consider edge cases, such as strings with all identical characters or strings where the length is 1. How do these affect your approach?

Finally, ensure your implementation runs efficiently, especially since the maximum length of the string can be up to 100,000 characters. Think about the time complexity of your sorting and character counting.

questionNotes: The input string is guaranteed to be palindromic.
s consists of lowercase English letters.
Return the lexicographically smallest palindromic permutation of s.
